caption: Table 1: Comparison of different algorithms for distributed stochastic optimization under smooth nonconvex objectives. “Per-iter Comm.” denotes the number of per-iteration communications or neighbors (degree) for each agent. “Based Graph” represents the number of required graph topologies during the entire training procedure. “Trans. Iter.” represents the number of transient iterations. The notation Õ(·) hides all the polylogarithmic factors.
description: The table compares various distributed stochastic optimization algorithms under smooth non-convex objective functions.  It shows the number of communications per iteration for each agent, the type of graph topology used, the number of graph topologies used across the entire process, and the number of transient iterations. The notation Õ(·) in the table hides polylogarithmic factors for easier readability.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of different algorithms for distributed stochastic optimization under smooth nonconvex objectives. “Per-iter Comm.” denotes the number of per-iteration communications or neighbors (degree) for each agent. “Based Graph” represents the number of required graph topologies during the entire training procedure. “Trans. Iter.” represents the number of transient iterations. The notation Õ(·) hides all the polylogarithmic factors.
description: This table compares several algorithms for distributed stochastic optimization focusing on smooth non-convex objective functions.  It contrasts the algorithms based on several key aspects: the number of communications per iteration for each agent, the network size, the type of graph topology used, and the number of transient iterations before linear speedup is achieved. The notation Õ(·) simplifies the complexity by hiding polylogarithmic factors.
